summary: This document is an email chain between prosecutors and defense attorneys in the US v. Maxwell case, discussing technical issues with discovery production, specifically problems with viewing thousands of images and documents, discrepancies in counts of 'highly confidential' materials, and the status of efforts to resolve these deficiencies. It reveals significant challenges in providing the defense with accessible evidence, including nude/sexualized images seized from Epstein's devices.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Partner at Haddon, Morgan & Foreman, P.C. representing Ghislaine Maxwell; she is corresponding with prosecutors about numerous discovery deficiencies, including unviewable files, metadata issues, and access to 'highly confidential' images.

persons.name: Jeff Pagliuca
persons.context: Copied on the email chain as part of Maxwell's defense team; involved in discussions regarding discovery issues.

persons.name: Bobbi Sternheim
persons.context: Copied on the email chain as part of Maxwell's defense team; involved in discussions regarding discovery issues.

connections.description: Menninger is a defense attorney representing Maxwell in the criminal case, as indicated by her advocacy regarding discovery access for her client.
Pagliuca is part of Maxwell's defense legal team, copied on critical discovery correspondence.
Sternheim is part of Maxwell's defense legal team, copied on critical discovery correspondence.
Both are defense attorneys on the same legal team representing Ghislaine Maxwell, collaborating on discovery issues.

events.title: Scheduled Trial Date for US v. Maxwell
events.description: The email mentions November 29, 2021, as the firm trial date for the case against Ghislaine Maxwell.

events.title: Evidence Review Meeting in New York
events.description: Defense attorney Laura Menninger met with prosecutors in New York the week of April 13, 2021, to review evidence, including 'highly confidential' material on hard drives.

locations: 500 Pearl (presumably a government building in New York where evidence was reviewed)
MDC (Metropolitan Detention Center, where Ghislaine Maxwell was held)
Denver, CO 80203 (address of Haddon, Morgan & Foreman, P.C., Laura Menninger's law firm)
Epstein's residence (source of seized CDs and devices)
Epstein's private island (mentioned in context of a 3D 'lazer scan' that was part of discovery)
keyFacts: Prosecutors and defense were dealing with massive discovery problems: thousands of Bates-numbered documents were corrupt, unviewable, missing images/natives, or had other technical issues, hindering Maxwell's ability to review evidence.

A significant discrepancy existed regarding the number of 'highly confidential' (nude/sexualized) images: the defense was initially told ~2,100 from Epstein's devices, but an FBI report indicated ~33,747 images and 895 videos, prompting confusion and follow-up.

The government resisted providing copies of 'highly confidential' images (containing nudity) to the defense, citing a protective order, and only allowed review under supervision, which the defense argued imposed an 'extraordinary cost' and impeded trial preparation.
Discovery included a 3D laser scan of Epstein's private island, which had previously been difficult to produce in a viewable format.

The email chain shows active, technical conferral between prosecution and defense teams in the months leading up to the November 2021 trial date, highlighting the complexity and volume of digital evidence in the case.
